text: Allright, bowl bid ridin' here for  E.S.U. Fourth down on the Georgia  Tech 18. 4 ticks left. Kane sets 'em  down.
smashing into the mud, as a football OFFENSIVE LINE comes set, frosted breath steaming across to: The DEFENSIVE LINE digging in, ready to explode.

E.S.U. quarterback, barking signals. The ball is snapped, and we go to SLOW MOTION as the lines crash together in t slop. Joe rolls to the right, looking downfield. A huge DEFENSI END bears down on him. Joe jukes. The end whips on by,  grabbing for jersey, slipping off. But big NUMBER 75 is  closing the gap. On the run, Joe releases a desperation p toward the end zone, just as 75 catches him and buries hi face-down in the swamp. We FOLLOW THE BALL, spiraling through the slanting rain. GRIFFEN, black running back, glances back for it, two  DEFENSIVE BACKS with him. All three leap in unison, climb as high as they can, clutching, clawing for the ball. The ball floats down, kisses off the tangle of fingers, splas to the ground, and rolls to a stop in the mud. Incomplete The BANG of the final gun snaps us back to LIVE ACTION. Joe on his knees in the muck, stares at the goal line, th drops his head in defeat.
Betraying little emotion, Coach SAM WINTERS, wiry, intens early 50's, takes off his headset, lets it drop, heads ac the field.
Coach, this is the second year in a  row you've failed to go to a bowl  game. Do you feel your program's in  decline?
Coach Winters stands outside his office surrounded by  reporters, a bouquet of microphones stuck in his face.
(keeping his cool) No, we're just a young team on the  verge. We'll be back in a major bowl  next year.

Elsewhere in the locker room, we pick up a weary, mud- splattered Joe Kane taking off his pads in front of his  locker. ALVIN MACK, black linebacker, comes by. Alvin exu danger; big, fast and hostile on the field, slightly surl a sense of repressed anger off it.
Good throw, Joe. It was there.
So was half their team. (trailing off) Shit, another Christmas at home.
Next year, man. Next year we sell  out. Next year we dominate.
still fielding questions.
You still need a deep threat or a  breakaway back to go with Joe Kane.  What are you gonna do to address  this need?
(a little edgy) Stop wastin' my time talkin' to you  guys for a start.
As Winters gets up to go, we hear:
I'm not gonna lead you into the fog  here, Sam...
CHANCELLOR GRANT WILSON, 60, grey-haired eminence, sits b his desk. Seated across from him are Coach Winters and GA HOWARD, 50, the Athletic Director.

I'm concerned about our Program.  It's always been a source of pride  to our students and alumni, but two  straight so-so seasons are having a  damaging effect on our fund-raising,  both public and private.
(half-joking) Then stop raising the entrance  requirements on me. We never could  have gotten Alvin Mack in here under  the new guidelines.
As Chancellor, my first responsibility  is to the academic interests of this  University.
Wilson points to a representation of a football field aff to the wall. A football rests on the 40 yard line, which marked 160 million. The end zone (60 yards away) is  $400,000,000.

At a time when we're committed to a  400 million dollar building program,  alumni donations are down 15% the  last two years. Because they've also  voiced their displeasure to their  legislators, we can expect a  corresponding drop in state funds.
The Athletic Fund is suffering too.  Season tickets sales are off,  merchandising's slow...
You layin' all this at my door?  There's been a recession on.

Yes, but the heaviest drop has been  from the big donors, the 100,000  dollar club. These people are  recession proof. They sit in my box  every game, and they're much more  generous when we're ranked and going  to bowl games. Two of them, as you  know, are on the Board of Regents,  including the Chairman.
What are you trying to say to me,  Grant? After 12 years, my job's in  jeopardy?

I'm not prepared to discuss your job  right now; I just want you to be  aware of the situation. The alumni  and the legislature are unhappy and  they vote with their checkbooks. I  don't pretend to be an expert on  football, Sam, and I'll deny that  this conversation ever took place,  but I do know we need to win next  year.

Coach Winters flanked by two assistant coaches, HUMES and CLAYTON, walks down a cavernous tunnel beneath the stands a waiting car. At the end of the tunnel, a scarecrow EFFI of Coach Winters hangs from an overhead pipe.
(ignoring the effigy) Tickets are in your coat. Itinerary  and player profiles are in your  briefcase. We got a 9:00am tomorrow  in Philly with this kid Darnell  Jefferson.
Coach Winters stops, looks up at the effigy. Humes and Cl fear an outburst, a display of rage.
Looks like I've lost weight.
That's it. He strides on. Humes and Clayton race to catch up.
This kid's the gamebreaker we've  been lookin' for.
A Boeing 737 roars into the night sky.
Had a 108 yard kickoff return against  Taft. Michigan's been down to see  him twice.

Winters, Humes, Clayton and Joe Kane sit across from DARN JEFFERSON and REVEREND WALLACE in a tattered parlor room. Other boys of various ages and color look in from the  adjoining door. Darnell is black, good-looking, street-hi the letters D.J. shaved in block letters into his fade.

Darnell, you have the potential to  start for us as a freshman. That 108  yard kickoff return you made against  Taft? One of the greatest runs I've  ever seen a high school player make.  Now, Michigan is set at tailback for  two years. You won't play till you're  a junior. With Joe here gettin' you  the ball, runnin' 28 Thunder right,  you'll be All-American with us as a  Sophomore.
Yes, but I'm really more concerned  with Darnell's education. He came  here late. He's got some catching up  to do.

Believe me, education is the first  priority in our program. That's why  all the players are smarter than me.  After all, a football coach is smart  enough to understand the game, but  dumb enough to think it's important.
This gets a little chuckle from the Reverend. It was inte to.
We see a run-down tenant SHACK on the edge of a large cot field.

Two rooms. Dirt floor. Two-foot Christmas tree on an appl cart. Alvin Mack's MOTHER opens a Christmas present as Al and his TWO SISTERS look on. It's an ENGRAVED LIONSHEAD  DOORKNOCKER, the kind you'de find on the door of an afflu home. The inscription reads THE MACK'S. Alvin's mother th it's beautiful, but isn't sure what to do with it.
It's real pretty, Alvin.
When I turn pro, I'll get you the  house to go with it.

Winters' daughter LOUANNE, 20, is on the phone with her  father. Louanne is sexy, clothes too tight, but good-natu somewhat needy and loyal as a labrador. She holds a hopel out-of-style sweater her dad's given her for Christmas.
(lying) It's real nice, Dad.
Winters sits on the bed, eating Chinese take-out, the pho cradled in his neck, talking to Louanne.
I knew you'de like it, Lou. Merry  Christmas. Put some fresh flowers on  your Mom's grave for me. I'll be  home in a couple days.
Battered and old, in a declining Pennsylvania neighborhoo hard by a STEEL WORKS.

Joe sits on the couch with his older brother, FRANK, watc the bowl game he would have been in, had E.S.U. won their last game. His FATHER, a grizzled man in his fifties, nod in and out in a tattered armchair. All three have been  drinking beer, their empties scattered around. Frank toss Joe an Iron City beer.
Have another Vitamin I, Joey. Didn't  think we'de see you here this  Christmas, little brother.
You won't next year.
(getting up) Yeh, well we won't rent your place  on the couch.
As Joe's father heads for the kitchen, he hangs his empty beer can, by the pull tab, on a branch of the Christmas t We see that the whole tree is covered with cans.
Darnell talks on a pay phone in the hall.
You're from E.S.U?
Yeh. I was just sittin' here by the  fire doin' my homework, and decided  to give you a call. See how you're  doin'.
We see who Darnell is talking to: AUTUMN HALEY, beautiful black girl, stylish, long straight hair, definitely not  street.
Coach Winters has been telling me  about you. I'm looking forward to  seeing you when you come to visit.  I'll be your guide. You are coming  to visit aren't you?
We PULL BACK and REVEAL Autumn in an office with 15 other telephones, a coed on every one. ASST. COACH MYERS superv with a clipboard of names and numbers.

Joe leads Darnell down to the end of the tunnel, where Au is waiting. He introduces them. She's even more attractiv than Darnell thought she'd be. She takes Darnell's hand and leads him out onto the field where he's greeted by the E.S.U. BAND playing the school  fight song. The CHEERLEADERS whip into action, legs kicki pom-poms whirling. The band parts and Darnell walks out into the 90,000 seat stadium, an awesome sight for any young man. Autumn point to the giant DIAMOND VISION SCOREBOARD. Darnell's name an picture appear. The stadium P.A. ANNOUNCER cuts in.
Now for the starting line-up for the  E.S.U. Timber Wolves. At tailback,  number 20, Darnell Jefferson!!
You got that right.
Darnell, in his excitement, does a little end-zone dance. Slaps hands with Joe.
Romantic, Ivy-League look, lit by soft-glo footlights. Da and Autumn walk, side by side, stopping outside Autumn's  dorm.
Thanks for showin' me around, Autumn.  I don't meet too many females like  you. You got a lotta class. Real  efficacious. Maybe I'll check you  out in the fall.
I hope so, Darnell.
He leans down to kiss her. She hesitates, not sure about  this, then comes forward, kisses him on the lips, starts let it deepen, then breaks it off.
Good night.
As he watches her go up the steps, we go to:

Early February: It's National Decision Day and Darnell's  home is under seige. Reporters. Microphones. Television  cameras. Darnell steps out onto the porch wearing an ESU  jersey with #1 emblazoned on it.
Now you know where I'm going and  what we're indubitably going to be.
MUSIC and TITLES END.

A hot, late summer day. Over the deserted Quad, we see th title: 6 MONTHS LATER. It fades and we MOVE TO REVEAL a city BUS pulling up at a curb adjacent to the Quad. Off steps Darnell, carrying on battered suitcase. Joe Kane and BUD LITE KAMINSKY, offens line tackle, are there to greet him.
Hey, Darnell, Welcome to E.S.U.
(shaking hands) Yeh, good to see you guys. What  happened to the band and the dancin'  honies?
Regular students don't come back for  two weeks yet. Not that they woulda  been here. Now that you've enrolled,  you're just another wormshit freshman.

A dorm devoted exclusively to football players. Luxurious lounges, study halls, saunas, recreation and media rooms. Spacious living quarters. A world unto itself. Joe and Bud usher Darnell into his room.
Here's your room. If you need anything  call the hall manager.
Darnell looks around, taking it all in. He tries to be co but this is easily the nicest room he's ever had.
See ya later. Freshman Placement  test tomorrow at nine. McKinnley  Hall.
Joe and Bud start down the hall. Darnell turns back into room, then starts to pace off it's dimensions, heel to to
College hang-out, bar, catering to athletes and their  admirers. A black HARLEY DAVIDSON, driven by Joe Kane wit Darnell on the back, pulls up at the curb. They get off,  head inside.

Joe and Darnell pass a table of three girls, conspicuous  among them is Louanne Winters. Joe and Darnell give her a nod and proceed on to a table where three fellow players  wait: Bud Lite, BOBBY COLLINS, good-looking, silver-tongu ladies man and 2nd string quarterback, and STEVE LATTIMER heavily muscled, surf-punk defensive end. Between them is large pitcher of beer.
Uh, oh, the Lead Dog is back. There  goes my cover of the media guide.
Hey, Bobby, Lats, how ya doin? This  is Darnell Jefferson, freshman  tailback.
How ya' doin'?
I was hopin' you'de have rolled your  bike or somethin'. Nothin' serious,  just enough to keep you out for the  season.

(pouring himself some  beer) No such luck, Backup Man. But I'll  try to engineer a few blowouts. Get  you get some mop-up time. (studying Lattimer) Shit, Lats, you look buffed, man.  You put on some weight?
35 lbs. Spent the summer in the gym.  I'm tired of watchin' you guys play.  I intend to start this year.
You get any bigger, you can play  offense.
Yeh, but don't I have to get dumber  too?

Bud takes a good-natured swipe at him. Lattimer deflects Joe notices Bobby looking over at Louanne. She gives Bobb surreptitious little wave to come over and sit with her. gives her the "just a minute" sign.
You still seein' Louanne?
Yeh. Now and then, when the tide  rises. Don't want her to think this  is some kind've exclusive deal.
Coach finds out you're nailin' his  daughter, you'll be playin' dorm  ball.
I'll bail before that. Besides, this  is what he gets for not startin' me.
Bobby laughs and heads over to Louanne's table, as Joe po himself another beer. Alvin enters the bar, goes to Joe's table, plops a copy o Sports Illustrated down in front of Joe.
Hey, man, you seen this?
On the cover is a picture of Joe and ONE OTHER QUARTERBAC TIM WAYMEN. The coverline reads, HEISMAN HOPEFULS: THE YE OF THE QUARTERBACK.
(ribbing Joe) You must be some very bad-ass  motherfucker.
Joe stares at the cover. He's more stunned than elated.
Jesus...
What? You didn't know?
I knew there was gonna be an article.  I didn't know it was gonna be on the  cover.
Shit, we do all the work. You get  all the pub. Too bad we're not allowed  to hit you in practice. Be fun to  kick the shit out of a Heisman Trophy  Candidate.
I guess you'll have to wait till we  get to the pros.
(to Darnell) Beer boy, get me some.
Are you serious?
Does it look like I'm serious?
Joe drains his beer, pours another. Lattimer starts to re form the article.

Listen to this. "E.S.U. has a solid  nucleus returning, but the  Timberwolves, coming off two  disappointing seasons, will only go  as far as the strong right arm of  Heisman Candidate Joe Kane will take  them." That right, Joe? You gonna  lead us to the promised land?
I'm gonna lead... but can you follow?
Muted chuckles, but set faces. The challenge accepted. Jo chugs his beer, pours another.

The crowd from the 911 (Bud, Alvin, Lattimer, Darnell, Bo and Louanne) follow Joe down the hill behind the bar towa a busy two-lane highway. Joe, a little drunker than the  others, starts HOWLING at the moon like a Timber Wolf. Th others join in.
What are we doin', Joe?
(slightly slurred) There's something I wanta try. Gotta  wake up our Mojo. Start settin' the  tone for the season.
This is not a good time to be settin'  anything. You're in no shape...
Suddenly Joe makes a dash out onto the highway.
Joe, c'mon Joe, don't be an asshole.  Joe! God-damnit, why's he always  doin' shit like this? Coach'll fuckin'  kill me. Alvin, go get him, will ya?
Hell no, you go get his ass. Crazy  motherfucker.
Joe stands on the white line, cars and trucks whizzing by then lies down on his back, arms at his side.
Cars and trucks blast toward us, roar on by, right on top us, honking, spraying grime, shaking the asphalt. Bud and the others on the side of the road are increasing worried now.
Fuck this shit.
Pissed off, Bud sprints out to the white line. The draft- wake of a passing truck almost blows him over.
C'mon, Joe, that's enough. Let's get  the hell outa here. What if somebody  drifts or crosses the line to pass?
What's the matter, Bud? Can't you  follow?
Bud hesitates a second, scared, but stung by this dare.
(torn) God-damnit, god-damnit. Shit.
Bud can't fight it. He lies down on the line, his head  touching Joe's feet. Joe begins to HOWL again. Bud joins Alvin and the others can't believe it.
Startin' to look like a loaf of Wonder  bread out there.
They're makin' us look like pussies,  ya know. Standin' here suckin' our  thumbs.
(to Alvin) Yeh, and there's nobody from the  Defense out there.
Bobby and Lattimer look at each other a beat. Time to ant up. Both turn to Alvin.
What are you lookin' at? You think  you're bad?
Alvin snorts in disgust and starts out onto the blacktop. Bobby and Lattimer smile, go to follow. Louanne grabs Bob holds him back.
(vaguely sexual) Bobby, be careful, o.k? Please, be  careful.

Bobby smiles, grabs her ass, pulls her to him, gives her long, passionate kiss, then sprints out to the white line leaving her breathless. Alvin, Bobby and Lattimer lie down in front of Bud. Now  there's a line of five, a human highway median. Everybody scared shitless, howling their lungs out. Louanne and Darnell watch from the side of the road.
This guy do this kinda shit a lot?  They never mentioned this in  recruiting.
Finally, Joe laughing wildly, jumps up and they all scram back to safety. Out of breath, but pumped up, they exchan exhilarated high fives. Alvin just shakes his head.

Twenty freshman football players, including Darnell, are  scattered at tables around the room, writing furiously in test booklets, as a PROCTOR paces the room. Darnell start to write an answer, stops, stumped. Worried, he looks at clock, goes on to the next page.
Darnell and Joe walk across campus. Darnell carries a  gleaming, chromed TROPHY with a football player on top. H still thinking about the test.
I don't know... I left a lot of 'em  blank.
Don't worry, you'll do all right.  Lotta people don't finish.
(not convinced) Yeh.
What are you doin' with the trophy?
Coach Winters asked me to bring it  to the meeting. I don't know what  for.
Suddenly Darnell sees Autumn walking across the Quad.
I'll see ya at the meeting. (handing him the trophy) Take this for me, will ya?
Joe starts to protest, but Darnell is already off, racing across the Quad, quickly catching up with Autumn.
Hey, Autumn, hold up! What're you  doing here? I thought students didn't  come back for two weeks.
(rather coolly) I came back early to see a friend.
You're looking fresh, Autumn. A  package of pulchritudiness. What  about getting together later tonight?  Maybe get a pizza? They got pizza in  this town don't they?
I can't tonight.
How about tomorrow night?
I don't think it's a real good idea  for us to see each other, Darnell.
What's the matter? I'm not good enough  for you all of a sudden? Too young,  is that it? I'm not, ya know. They  held me back a year.
No, it's not that... I've got a  boyfriend.
Did you have this boyfriend when you  showed me around?
(reluctant to admit  it) Yes.
Yeah, well, it didn't seem to bother  you then. I'm willing to overlook it  now.
I was mad at him.
For what?
I caught him with another girl. A  white girl.
And you're still with this nigger?
She nods, slightly embarrassed.
Look, I got to get going, Darnell.  I'm sorry. I didn't mean to lead you  on. I'm glad you came here.
She starts walking away.
Wait a minute. I can at least walk  with you, can't I? Nothin' wrong  with that.
She speeds up. He speeds up.
I'm in a hurry.
I can keep up. I run the forty in  four-four.
She's just about to say something when RAY GRIFFEN arrive Ray's the starting tailback, black, handsome, clean-cut,  well-spoken, middle class.
Hey, Autumn --
This is exactly what Autumn didn't want to happen. Ray an Darnell eye each other like a couple of roosters.
Hi, Ray. This is...
(cutting in, offering  his hand) Darnell Jefferson. (pointedly) Tailback.
(shaking Darnell's  hand) Ray Griffen. (just as pointedly) Starting tailback.
I know. That's why they recruited  me.
Autumn can't believe he said this. She starts to interjec something to break the tension, but never gets the chance
The two guys they recruited before  you are handing out Gatorade now. (making the jerkoff  motion) Better start strengthening your wrist.
We'll see. (departing, to Ray) Give my best to Miss Lilly.
Autumn's mortification is complete.
(to himself) What the hell is that supposed to  mean?
Establish the new, modern KELLER CENTER, home of the E.S. Athletic Department.

The football meeting room. A quarter amphitheatre. The  Freshman, including Darnell, down in front. Nervous, talk very little, eyes playing over the pictures of former E.S greats arranged on the Wall of Honor. Behind them, the Upperclassmen, bantering, conversation  punctuated with laughter. A door opens. The Assistant Coaches file in. The room hus immediately. Coach Winters walks in. The Upperclassmen br into applause; the Freshmen quickly take their cue and jo in.
Good to see you again, gentlemen. (catching sight of  Darnell) Jefferson, either take off the earring  or put on a dress.
The upperclassmen hoot, as Darnell, embarrassed, takes of his earring.
I wanna talk a little about what  we're trying to do here. There are  many highly respected people who  feel football is about preparation  for life.
The players nod reverentially at this established axiom o the football cannon.

These people are full of shit. You  see, football is not like life. (pause) It's better. More exciting, more  intense, more fun. In life, people  are always wondering how they measure  up; whether they're getting ahead or  fallin' behind. In football, you  know. Every week you get a chance to  show what you're made of, a chance  to demonstrate the physical and  personal qualities that all those  poor bastards who can't play this  game are left to agonize about.
Spreading smiles all around. It's good to be a football  player.

Last year we didn't make enough of  those chances. Last year everyone  felt we let the school down. Fuck  the school. We let ourselves down. (pointing to the Wall  of Honor) We let down a great tradition, a 120- year-old Line of Champions.
The smiles are gone. Lots of set faces now. Shame. anger, retribution.

Any football program worth the name  is a special brotherhood, an elite  corps of warriors, a select group of  knights. That first time our starting  unit takes the field, the first time  we huddle up; that's our inner circle,  that's our Round Table. If I were an  upperclassman, I'd be real nervous  about my seat, cause we got some  very talented new-comers this year.  Guys who want a place at the Table. (producing Darnell's  trophy from behind  the podium) This is the trophy one of our  freshman, Darnell Jefferson, won as  a Pennsylvania State High School  First Team All-American. You know  what this says to me?
The freshmen are hanging on every word.
Not a god-damn thing.
He smashes the trophy on the podium, breaking it in half, shattering the base. Darnell and the other freshmen are a The upperclassmen stifle laughs, particularly Ray Griffen

(to the freshmen) Everybody here was a high school All- American. (to all the players) Whatever any of you have done before  is out the window. We're startin'  over. Ground zero. The Table is empty.  Are you ready?
The upperclassmen nod, steely, purposeful. We go to the  freshmen. They're not so sure.
Passing drills. Joe Kane takes a snap, fades to pass, thr an out. The ball sails two feet over the receiver's head. Joe's angry with himself.
(to Winters) He's too pumped up. Tryin' to win  the damn Heisman on every throw. I'm  not sure he's ready for all this  hype.
Little late to be worryin' about  that. If we don't follow up the Sports  Illustrated cover with something,  it'll look like we didn't believe in  our own player.
Don't worry, Joe's a tough kid. He'll  be allright.

Scrimmage. Joe hands off to Darnell. He sweeps right, cut it up, blows past the end. In a spectacular display of br field running, Darnell breaks to the sideline, cuts back, eluding the corner back, and stiffarms the safety. Alvin, pursuing the play, finally tackles him from behind, strip the ball at the same time. There's a wild scramble for th fumble. Darnell is crushed under the pile, as the defense recovers it, ruining an otherwise brilliant run. The players unpile to reveal Darnell, writhing on the gro the wind knocked out of him. Ray Griffen runs by to take place.
Hey, nice writhing, Jefferson. You  got all the moves.
(shouting to the team) Allright, move it up. Let's go, 15  yards, run the next play.
The scrimmage moves up 15 yards leaving Darnell behind.  Winters sprints over to Lattimer, grabs him by the face m

Cut the necktie tackle horseshit.  You think you're in some kinda  highlight reel? He left you huggin'  air. Target his guts. Drive right  through his abdomen. I wanta see  snot bubbles in his nose. I wanta  see shit in his underwear.
Lattimer nods chastised. Winters moves over to check on  Darnell.
You injured, Jefferson, or just hurt?
(gasping) What do you mean?
If you're hurt, you can still play.  If you're injured you can't. Are you  hurt or are you injured?
I think I'm just hurt.
O.k., then get up.
Winters extends a hand. Darnell grabs it, struggles shaki to his feet

Nice run. Think what it coulda done  for us if we still had the ball. (handing him the ball) This is a football. I want you to  carry it with you wherever you go.  Never let it out of your sight. (to the rest of the  team) Any of you see him on campus, take a  swipe at the ball. Try to knock it  out of his hands. Recover it. (to Darnell again) If anybody, but you, returns this  ball to me, you'll wish you'de never  been born.
Winters wheels off leaving a wobbly Darnell alone with hi football.
This isn't gonna get it, goddamnit.
Winters, mad as hell, is berating his assistant coaches w are sitting, cowed in his office.

I see tackling, but I don't see  hitting. I see effort, but I don't  see ferocity. What do you think,  they're gonna motivate themselves?  Football's just a game to most of  these kids. This is our program, our  livelihood. It's our job to make  them care as much about it as we do.  Make them hate me if you have to.  It'll bring them together, give them  a focus. So get off your butts and  put the fear of God in these guys.

Dead tired players toweling off, dressing. The trainer's  room is crowded with aching, cramped-up, contused players Across the way, Lattimer lifts weights, alone in the weig room. Clayton and Humes consider this from outside Winter office.
Shit, Lattimer's an animal all of a  sudden. Benchin' 450. He's gotta be  on somethin'.
What, steroids? Why do you always  think my guys are juicin'?
I don't know... he's on the punt  team for three years, then gains 35  pounds of rip in one summer and an  attitude to go with it.
Winters, who's heard all this, comes by.

We're not doctors, gentlemen. The  NCAA has testing programs for this.  Let's let them worry about it. (to Clayton) Besides, it's not that hard to put  on 35 pounds in a summer, if you  really hit the gym.
Winters walks on into his office. Clayton nods, realizing this subject is now closed.

Darnell walks in, wrung out from the day's practice, stum to the bed where he sees something that stops him - lying there is his PENNSYLVANIA STATE ALL AMERICAN TROPHY. Coac Winters actually smashed a replica. A smile appears on  Darnell's tired face.
For football players only. Bud Lite moves through the  cafeteria line.
What you got tonight?
Choice of three entrees. Shrimp,  lasagna, T-bone steak.
Tough choice. I'll take all three.
What a surprise.
at another table with Alvin and several other black playe Lattimer is the only white.
When do they give ya the scores on  that Placement Test?
Who cares? I flunked it three times,  before I got in.
Long as you're in the program, they'll  get you through. Maybe not with a  degree, but they'll keep you eligible.  Just don't do nothin' embarrassing  they can't cover you for.
Hell, they even give Alvin copies of  his tests in advance. He sells 'em  for a hundred bucks a pop to people  in his class. 'Course he's gotta  have somebody read 'em to him.
Fuck you, doughboy. I can read. See  that shoe? (points to his shoes) That says Nike.
I still don't wanna flunk that test.  I wanta get a degree.
What do you think, nigger? You're  gonna be on the Supreme Court? All  you need to know is how to sign an  N.F.L. contract.

Darnell's stung by this. He'd like to think of himself as capable of more. Suddenly, Coach Winters appears at the door, a surprise  visitor to the training table. All the players wearing  baseball caps, quickly doff them. Winters is angry.

What's the matter with you guys?  You're supposed to be a team. Winning  depends on thinking and acting and  going to war together. But you don't  even eat like a team. You eat like  two teams. A white one and a black  one. What do I have to do? Make out  a seating chart? Now get up. Move  around. Mix it up. Now!
The players all look at each other, then reluctantly get and change tables. Darnell sits next to Joe.
(mock introduction) Hi there. Darnell Jefferson. I'm a  young black man.
Hey, glad to meet ya. Joe Kane,  Caucasian. So what doya think a that  new Garth Brooks album?
I love that motherfucker.
Coach Winters surveys the scene, sees that all the tables are integrated now.
That's more like it.
He turns and walks on out. Immediately, the players begin drift back to their old tables.

Joe, Bud Lite and Bobby Collins, all suffering from vario aches and pains are getting Naperson and analgesic balm o of the non-prescription drug cabinet. Joe pops a Nap and  looks across to the weight room where a stunning co-ed CA SCHAEFFER works a knee lift. Camille's the perfect marria of Southern patrician beauty and athletic confirmation. J leaves the others, heads over, pokes his head in.
How ya' doin'?
Fine.
Little late to be workin' out, isn't  it?
(with a little edge) Only time I could get in here when  the football team wasn't usin' it.
(trying to get a rise  out of her) Well, if it wasn't for the football  team, might not be a weight room to  use. You tryin' to firm up a little,  or what?
(unfazed) Don't need to firm up. I'm  strengthening my knee. Had  arthroscopic surgery.
Had my knee scoped once too. When  you're finished here, maybe we could  get a yogurt, compare scars.
Sorry, I don't date football players.  They're all full of themselves. I  saw you on the cover of Sports  Illustrated, so you're probably worse  than most.
That's real open minded of you. So  you won't consider doin' anything  with me?
No.
Well at least tell me what happened  to your knee. What'd you do? Fall  outa your convertible?
Camille stops her knee lift, turns to Joe. We think she's going to fire on him. Wrong.
You know, there's maybe one thing  I'd do with you.
What's that?
Tennis. I'll play tennis with you.
Camille starts to walk away.
Tennis. You mean now? It's raining.

smashing a two-fisted forehand right at us, grunting with the exertion. Joe scrambles to get it back, but Camille's world-class player. She attacks with a vengeance, blastin every shot ala Jimmy Connors, as Bud Lite and Bobby Colli watch, amazed. We begin a SERIES OF CUTS detailing Camille's relentless  dismantling of Joe: Camille drilling a backhand down the  line, Joe barely getting it back to the net. Camille hitt a powerhouse service ace, Joe lunging and whiffing the re Camille crushing another forehand. Joe crushes it back, s it over the fence and into the parking lot. Camille servi again at match point. Joe pops up a weak return. Camille  puts it away with a powerhouse overhead, the ball almost  knocking Joe down. He flings his racket against the fence Camille comes to the net to shake hands, but Joe hangs ba
Thanks for the game, Heisman. You  took it really well.
And she walks away along to the net. Joe goes after her,  pissed.
What's this Heisman crap?
Camille's taken aback, not realizing she'd struck a nerve
I didn't say anything about being a  Heisman candidate. I don't go around  strokin' myself about it. So what's  this shit you're givin' me?
I... I'm sorry... I just figured you  were probably kissin' yourself in  the mirror every morning.
You figured wrong.
Now Joe walks away and Camille goes after him.
So what do you want, an apology? I  just gave you one.
I want a rematch.
A rematch?
Some other sport. I took my beating.  You owe me one. Either that or we go  out.
Camille considers, tries to figure out what she'd dislike least, knowing it'd be cheap to choose neither.
I'll think about it.
Camille walks off, disappearing through the gate. Joe wal off in the other direction. Bud Lite and Bobby follow.
Real good date, Joe. Remind me to  take her out.

Opening day of school. We take CUTS of students arriving, football players checking out the new girls from atop the wall of the athletic dorm, Louanne and Autumn greeting  returning sisters at the sorority, students registering f classes etc.
Darnell sits across from WILLIAM SMITH, Academic Advisor.
Darnell, I've reviewed your placement  test and I'm afraid you failed to  meet our entrance requirements in  two areas.
What does that mean? I can't play  football?
No. It means you're going to have to  take some remedial classes, what we  call "zero level" courses.  Specifically Math 0 and English 0.
Darnell is clearly deflated by this painful indication of his academic standing.

You won't get college credit for  them, but they will help you prepare  to take the Placement Test again at  the end of the quarter. If you pass  at that time you'll be able to  officially enter the university and  take college level courses. You'll  still be able to take an American  History survey course, but it won't  count on your record until you pass  the Placement Test. But first things  first. To start, I'm approving a  tutor for you.
A tutor? I don't need no tutor.
Any tutor. And yes you do.

A meeting of the football brain trust; Coach Winters, Ath Director, GALEN HOWARD, a publicist, SHARON BRAVER, and t Sports Information Director (S.I.D.) LARRY NICHOLS. Also  present is Joe Kane, somewhat discomfited at being the ce of all this attention.
I think both Joe and the university  are best served by a straightforward  Heisman campaign. Nothing too  gimmicky.

We've compiled a mailing list of  around 1300 opinion makers;  newspapers, football writers, and  sports anchors. First we send them a  packet on Joe and his achievements.  Bio, stats, plus human interest stuff;  commitment to academics, charity  work, etc. Then we update it each  week with a postcard. Heisman voters  hate opening envelopes.
Joe is increasingly uneasy with all this.
I haven't really done any charity  work...
You're gonna start. We've got some  things lined up.

Unfortunately, because we weren't in  the top 20 last year, we only have  one network T.V. game to give Joe  national exposure. Although it's a  good one; Michigan. But we'll also  be taping all our other games and  buying satellite time. That way we  can produce our own highlight package  and interview pieces and send them  out to T.V. stations all over the  country for their sportscasts.
Any questions, Joe?
If Joe was uneasy before, he's overwhelmed now. He tries to show it. After all, who could turn down a Heisman camp Still it's a megaton of pressure.
Ah, no... I just... you really think  I got a shot to win this?

Hell, yes. Plus it's a good thing  for the program. Publicizes the  school, gives a boost to recruiting,  and it's a great thing for you. Jumps  up your draft position, the size of  your first contract, everything.  It's a hell of an opportunity.
All you gotta do is back it up on  the field, and we have no doubts  about that, cause we know "Kane is  Able."
Nichols holds up a black CAMPAIGN BUTTON with the phrase  "Kane is Able" enblazoned on it in gold letters. This get rise out of everyone except Joe, who's still not sure abo all this.
Joe lies on his bed, staring up at the ceiling, unable to get to sleep.
The phone rings. Camille, who's been asleep, rolls over a answers it.
Hello...
This is Joe Kane. What did you decide?
(still drowsy) What? (looking at the clock) It's 3:00 in the morning.
I wanta know what you decided.
I don't know... I couldn't think of  any other sports I could beat you  at.
Then I'll pick you up tonight at  6:00.
He hangs up.
What?
Autumn sits at a tutorial table, looking at her notes. Sh becomes aware of someone approaching. She looks up to see Darnell.
Hey, Autumn.
Hi, Darnell. What are you doin here?
My advisor says I need a tutor. Ya  know, just to get me over a couple  rough spots. (showing her a paper) I saw your name on this list. I  figured if you couldn't keep my  attention, nobody could.
I'm sorry, Darnell, but I've already  been assigned. You're gonna have to  find somebody else. I'm tutoring  Scott Sherman.
Not anymore. I asked Coach Winters  to switch us.
Coach Winters wouldn't do that.
Yeh he would. I'm a bigger prospect  than Sherman. (pointing across the  way) He's a lineman on the scout team.

Autumn looks back to where Darnell is pointing. Sure enou SCOTT SHERMAN is hard at work with another Tutor. Autumn  can't believe it. She tries to compose herself. Darnell sits down across the table from her.
C'mon Autumn, you could teach me  some real erudition.
(trying to whisper,  pissed) Will you stop using those big words.  It sounds ridiculous.
(serious about this) What doya mean? I'm improvin' myself.  I learn a new word out of the  dictionary every day. Mendacious,  pejorative, antithetical,  commensurate...
And you don't ever use them right.  Pretending to be smart is not the  same as being educated. Or erudite.  It's just a con. And it makes you  sound stupid, no matter how big a  prospect you are.
Darnell is genuinely hurt by this dose of reality. His  customary bravado melts away.
O.K... even more reason for you to  be my tutor. You already taught me  something.
Autumn, disarmed by his sudden humility, has no real rebu She would have had to tutor him anyway, but now she's hav trouble being angry about it.
At another table, looking distracted and bored as his TUT reads his history assignment to him. Alvin takes out a wa and puts the headphones on. WE HEAR A HORN BEEP.
Camille comes out the front door, summoned by the horn. S stops at the sight of something. We REVERSE TO REVEAL Joe his Harley.
We goin' on that?
Yeh. I thought we might take a ride.
I promised my dad I'd never get on  one of those.
What are you, one of these trust- fund princesses? It's fine for me to  play a game I don't know, but I ask  you to try somethin' different and  you hide behind your daddy.
He holds out a motorcycle helmet toward her, daring her. burns, but her competitiveness makes it impossible for he to decline this challenge.
(snatching the helmet) All right. But we go slow. No cowboy  stuff.
Joe smiles and kicks the starter. Camille climbs on and t roar off.
Just outside town. Joe and Camille come down the highway moderate speed. Camille's hanging on for dear life, but w can tell she's enjoying it.
This speed, o.k.?
Yeh, fine.
Good.
Joe immediately accelerates, throwing Camille's head back Her SHRIEK is lost in the whine of the engine, as they sp away from camera.
Slow down, damnit. Joe... Joe!

They approach a high-banked turn, beyond which appears to a long, sheer dropoff. Joe looks back at Camille, smiles  devilishly, not looking where he's going. Camille sees th heading straight for the edge.
(freaked) Joe, look out!!!
Too late. Joe brakes, fishtails, but goes over the top of the bank, off the edge, flying out into oblivion, Camille screaming.

As it plops down onto a wide LEDGE not visible from the r three feet below the top of the bank. Joe lands it, skids a professional stop, breaks into raucous laughter. Camill jumps off the bike, scared stiff and livid with anger.
How could you do that, you stupid  punk? It isn't funny, god-dammit,  you coulda killed us! You're crazy,  you know that...
Take it easy. I've done that a hundred  times. No big deal.
Oh, yeh? Then why are you shaking?
(embarrassed) I don't know... I guess cause I've  never done it with someone else on  the bike.
You just wanted to scare me. Are you  happy now?
Yeh, pretty much. And the scream was  even better than I thought it'd be.  Every dog within hearing distance  wants to mate with you now.

Camille's ready to throttle him, then something catches h ear. Sure enough, there are SEVERAL DOGS BARKING in the  distance. Joe smiles at her. She looks away, still angry, but amused in spite of herself.
Working class, sawdust floor, George Thoroughgood's "Who You Love" on the jukebox. Camille and Joe are sitting in booth. Joe putting away the beers.
You come here a lot?
Now and then. Why?
It's not exactly a campus favorite.  This is almost like hidin' out.
I like places where nobody knows me.  This too low-rent for you?
No, my dad owned a place like this.
Your dad? You mean he owned a chain  of these?

Not everybody with a Southern accent  has their own plantation. My dad  could never afford to send me here.  I learned to play tennis on public  courts. Mighta been able to play pro  someday, if I hadn't hurt my knee.
So you're just a scholarship jock  like me.
Yeh. You disappointed?
No, I've just never been out with a  jock before.
Is that what we're doin' here? Goin'  out?
I don't know. What doya think?
Joe gets up, takes Camille's hand and pulls her to her fe They dance to a slow song.
I think you're crazy for jeopardizing  your scholarship and a pro future by  jumping motorcycles off of highways.
Just tryin' to keep my edge, Camille.  The other guys look to me cause they  think I'll do anything. I lose that,  I'm just another guy, and we all get  our ass kicked.
I don't know, Joe. You scare me.
Joe roars in on his motorcycle. Parks. Starts inside. Fin himself face to face with a very unhappy Coach Winters.  Winters holds out his hand.
The keys.
Joe hesitates a second, then reluctantly hands over his  motorcycle keys.
I told you, as long as you're in  this program, you don't take  unnecessary risks off the field. A  man in contention for the Heisman  Trophy should be able to remember  that.
Joe nods, contrite. Winters just walks on off.
Autumn is tutoring Darnell, checking her lesson notes.
O.K., using the things we worked on  yesterday, I want you to write a two  or three page essay on some aspect  of your life. Something other than  football.
Like what?
Your father, maybe. You could write  about your dad.

Don't know that much about him. He  was off in Detroit workin' in a car  plant when I was born. Got laid off,  tried to rob a jewelry store to get  us some money. He died in prison.  Some kinda heart problem.
Autumn wasn't ready for this level of hardship. She tries press on gamely.
How about your mother?

She was always workin'. Usually two  jobs. Comin' home one night she  stopped to get us some root beer.  Got caught in a gang crossfire. Shot  three times... died on the way to  the hospital. You want me to write  about that?
(blown away) No...
Good, 'cause none of it's true.
Autumn jumps up.
(raising her voice) Jesus Christ, Darnell what a terrible  thing to do to somebody. That's not  funny. That's sick.
Autumn realizes she's in the library and sits back down.
Had ya goin', didn't I?
(soft library voice) No you didn't. You just... How could  you make up somethin' like that?
(contrite now) Sounded more interesting than the  truth. My mom took a vacation to  Chicago when I was 12. Never came  back. Don't know who my dad was.
Autumn's anger melts away in the face of this painful tru
Who took care of you?

I started hangin' with the J.B.M.,  gang-bangin'... Did some time in the  Hall. Reverand Wallace saw me playin'  football on a juvenile probation  team. Took me in, got me into high  school. Only reason they accepted me  was 'cause I could play football.  Sorta like here. Football saved my  life. I'd be nowhere without football.
Autumn just nods, still trying to take this all in.
Well, then... maybe you could write  about football this once.
Yeh, o.k... thanks. (pause) I've seen a lotta shitty things in  my life, Autumn. That's why I know  when I see somethin' good.
Autumn knows this is no line. He means it. She's seeing h with new eyes. Moved by his pain, engaged by his sincerit and more than a little taken by his regard for her.
across the room with his tutor.
Let's review the chapter I read you  yesterday. Which two city states  fought in the Punic Wars?
I dunno. Detroit and Buffalo.
C'mon, Alvin. You're gonna be tested  on this.
A video projector projects various football formations on the wall.
Okay, Alvin, this is Mississippi  State's offensive set. 2nd and 2 on  our 24. What defense are you in?
Eagle. Zipper. Hero. Unless the set  back shifts into the I.
Good. (slide changes) How about here? 3rd and 7.
Okie. Thunder. Lion.
What's your assignment?
Kill the Quarterback. (slide changes) Hit the tight end so hard his  girlfriend dies. (slide changes) Kill everybody.
Joe watches Bud Lite, Darnell, Alvin and Lattimer file in and unveil a life-size CARDBOARD STAND-UP of Joe's Sports Illustrated cover pose. They whoop it up, as Joe tries to muster some enthusiasm.

Autumn's pointing out a figure on a graph in Darnell's ma book. As she explains, Darnell leans close to kiss her. A quickly leans away, glances around to see if anyone saw  Darnell's attempt. Darnell laughs.

A group of football players sits in the back of the class As the HISTORY PROFESSOR lectures at the board, Darnell  furiously takes notes. Scott Sherman, seizing the opportu leans forward from the desk behind him and pokes the foot out of Darnell's left hand. Darnell, Scott and two other  FRESHMAN FOOTBALL PLAYERS spring out of their seats,  scrambling after the loose ball. The prof and the other  students watch appalled as Darnell and the others dive un chairs and overturn desks in pursuit of the elusive ball. Finally, Darnell, winded and disheveled, comes up with it He and the others quickly return to their seats. The prof looks at Darnell aghast.
Sorry... I lost my football.
Joe and Camille are locked up in a furious game of raquet Joe makes a wicked kill shot on the last point, and pumps fist in triumph. Camille, pissed at losing, throws her ra and stomps around.

Darnell and Autumn are having a daytime tutoring session a secluded patch of lawn. Darnell holds his football. As begins to read aloud from East of Eden, Autumn pokes the  ball out of his hand. They both scramble for it, Darnell  winding up slightly on top of her. They eye each other a  beat. Darnell bends down to kiss her. She lets herself ki him for a second, then gets up and starts to collect her  books.

Several of the players are gathered around a bulletin boa in the hall. The starting lineup for the first game has b posted. Darnell traces his finger from the designation  TAILBACK over to the name RAY GRIFFEN. He drops his eyes, obviously disappointed. Lattimer, meanwhile, is checking the defensive board. He  finds his name posted as a starting defensive end. Punchi the air, he dashes out of the building.
Yes!! Starting defense. Place at the  table. Whooo!! Yes!!

Lattimer, in his euphoria, races out into the lot, and be head-butting car windows. He breaks out three in a row, a yells in triumph, his forehead dripping blood. Winters, walking with the TEAM TRAINER, has seen this fro across the street. He knows there's something dark at wor here.
N.C.A.A. is gonna test half the team  before the game Saturday. Make sure  Lattimer knows about it.
The chairs are arranged in several circles, ten players t circle, like a bunch of formalized huddles. Coach Winters addresses the assembly.

As the veteran players know, we have  Pride Night every year before our  opening game. It's a chance to get  to know each other better, share  some thoughts, and bring us closer  together as a team. So to start off,  I'd like each player to tell the  others in his group what he likes  best about football and then what  he's most proud of off the field.  I've asked some of the seniors to  lead it off. Gentlemen.
I don't know... It's the battle. The  goin' to war with the other guys.  Hangin' together.
The team walks through several plays. They wear coats and ties, but no socks. Their ankles are taped.
Bein' different from everybody else.  Havin' our own dorm, stayin' in hotels  the night before games. Settin'  ourselves apart.

Before the game. An NCAA OFFICIAL gives Lattimer a little test tube to urinate in for his drug test. Lattimer goes  into one of the restroom stalls, reaches around to the ba of the tank, where a VIAL OF CLEAN URINE is taped. He pou it in the test vial.
Havin' a chance to be somebody. To  do somethin' that people look up to  you for. Your strength and your  courage. Not everybody can play  football. We're the lucky ones.
The thing I'm most proud of myself  for?
Darnell listening to a Walkman, is going through a pregam ritual by his locker; pivoting from leg to leg, switching the ball from arm to arm.
Just that I'm here. That I'm not  dead or in jail.
The great thing about football is  you can lose yourself in it.
Joe sits off in a corner by himself, his head back agains the wall, staring out into space, the only movement the  rhythmic tapping of his feet.
There's no time to think, to worry,  to have doubts. Everything else fades  away. You just move and react.
The best thing is when you dominate.  That feeling when you hit a guy real  good, really stick him, and you hear  that little moan.

Alvin, his ass-kicking game face on, walks over to where  Lattimer is finishing decorating his face with Indian war paint. They chuck each other's pads, then Lattimer opens mouth. Alvin spits into it. Then Lattimer spits into Alvi Darnell can't believe this shit.
You know it's killin' him, but you  feel great. It's just him and you,  and he's the one that's hurtin'.
We move in on the burning ferocity of Alvin's eyes and

The Players are bunched together in the tunnel, slapping  pads, yelling encouragement. Winters waves them forward.  They start to run down the tunnel. PLAYERS P.O.V. CAMERA runs with the players as the light at the end of t tunnel becomes larger and brighter. Crowd NOISE becomes l until finally the camera emerges into the stadium and the light and 95,000 VOICES ROAR. AND ROAR! AND ROAR! This is Big Time College Football.
E.S.U. announcer BRAD HARVEY and colorman, HARMON SLOAN a holding forth.

Welcome everybody to the Wolf Den  where the E.S.U. Timberwolves, led  by Heisman candidate Joe Kane, open  their season against the tough  Mississippi State Bulldogs under  head coach Jackie Sherrill.

The crowd stands, waving banners, as the E.S.U. kicker co forward and kicks the ball high into the fall sky. The  MISSISSIPPI STATE RETURN MAN fields the ball at the four  yard line and returns it to the 22 where he's buried. The defense trots out and huddles up.
All right, let's get evil. 60 minutes,  balls out. Let's open a can of kick- ass. Kill 'em all. Let the paramedics  sort 'em out.
The Mississippi State offense breaks it's huddle, comes t the line of scrimmage. Alvin, prowling behind the line, l eyes with the tailback, No.23.
Hey, 23, don't think I don't recognize  you, you little fuck.
The tailback looks away.
Hey, pay attention when I'm talkin'  to you, nigger. You're the guy that  shot my mother aren't you?
What?
You were tryin' to steal her fuckin'  car weren't you, cocksucker.
Shut up. I never heard of your mother.
On the sidelines, Darnell is watching this exchange.
(to Joe) What's Alvin saying to that guy?
Just gettin' himself pumped up.
He wasn't pumped up already?
(to tailback) Thought I'd never find you didn't  ya? But I got you now nigger, and  I'm gonna kill you motherfucker. I'm  gonna bust your guts open and watch  you die.

The ball is snapped. The quarterback pitches to the tailb as Alvin charges into the hole, screaming at the top of h lungs. The tailback, eyes wide with fear, cuts back, away from Alvin, where he's promptly crunched by Lattimer. The ball flies loose, there's a scramble, Alvin comes up with it. E.S.U. ball.
The bench and stands erupt as Lattimer and Alvin but head and trot off the field.
Atta baby, Alvin, heads up. Big pop,  Steve, way to stick 'em. (turning to Joe) O.K. Joe, let's go up top. Take it  to 'em right away.
Joe leads the offense on. A disappointed Darnell stands o the sidelines.
(in huddle) O.K. let's put the women and children  to bed, and go lookin' for dinner.  Don't let em up. 51 Strike, Orange  left. On 4.
Joe begins to howl like a wolf. The others join in. A pac of Timberwolves. They break the huddle, come to the line scrimmage. Bud Lite begins to sing.
Bali Hi, will call you, anytime, any  day. Here am I, your special island...
Bud lines up opposite a big, black DEFENSIVE TACKLE.
Shut up, snowflake. You think you're  in the school play?
No, Bali Hi, the endzone is calling.  And the highway runs right over your  ass.
Bullshit, you're gonna be my bitch,  baby. You gonna be my punk bitch.
(singing again) So long, farewell, auf Wiedersehen,  good night, I hate to go and leave  this pretty sight.

Joe hits the 4 count, and the ball is snapped. Bud Lite a the Big Tackle fire out. Bud drives a forearm into the st of the Black Tackle, doubling him over. The Black Tackle  comes back, slamming a forearm up under Bud's chin, snapp his neck back. Joe, meanwhile, fades to pass, pump fakes, steps up. Bud  Lite, chicken fighting the Black Tackle, sticks his finge in the Tackle's eyes, then cut-blocks him to the ground. Tackle falls on Bud, and smashes a fist into his ribs. Bu rolls him over. Joe spots his flanker back, MAURICE WARD, on a flag patte Lofts a perfect spiral to him in the corner of the endzon Touchdown. The crowd goes wild, as Bud Lite pushes off the Black Tac throat getting up from the pile. Joe pumps a fist in the  air, hugs Ward, as the team celebrates. MUSIC BEGINS.
It reads E.S.U. 28, Mississippi State 20. 4th Quarter.
Jefferson! In for Griffen.
Darnell jazzed at his first chance to see action, buttons his chinstrap, races onto the field.
2:05 left. Kane hands to Jefferson...

He takes a handoff, runs a trap up the middle, is hit by  THREE TACKLERS, clawing at the ball. They bring him down, but Darnell doesn't fumble. He gets up, still clutching t ball, and starts back to the huddle with it. The REFEREE  hustles after him.
Excuse me, son, but we're gonna need  that football for another couple  minutes.
Darnell, suddenly realizing, gives it up. Even Winters ha to laugh. We go to:
Lattimer, sacking the quarterback, tackling him high, rip his helmet off. Lattimer runs off the field, holding it u like a trophy. The gun sounds, the game is over.
Accepting congratulations from his staff.
Guess we'll be on the payroll for  another week.

head_text.subj: BUD LITE AND THE BLACK TACKLE

text: walking off the field together, both their jerseys blood- stained.
Good game, man. Really enjoyed it.
Yeh, you're a strong motherfucker.  Shitty singer though.
A reception of some sort for the players is in progress.  Darnell, looking a little lost, fills his cup from a punc bowl. A FAT CAT ALUMNUS approaches him.
Good to see ya in there, Darnell.  Way to hold on to that pigskin.
As he walks by, he slips an ENVELOPE into Darnell's coat  pocket. Darnell opens it to find a 50 dollar bill. Surpri he goes over to Alvin.
Hey, some guy just gave me a 50 dollar  bill.
Don't worry, you'll get 5 or 6 hundred  once you're startin', depending on  how you play.
But we're not supposed to get any  are we?

Hey, man, you can't live on $500 a  month scholarship money. And the NC  double assholes won't let us have  jobs, so you take your money where  you can get it. (taking Darnell's  envelope) I'll keep it for you, till you see  the light. Shit, they oughta be payin'  us anyway. Athletic Department gets  3 million just for goin' to a bowl  game.
Joe sits alone on his bed watching T.V. He's being interv in the locker room, a bouquet of microphones in his face.
This performance today -- two  touchdown passes, another you ran  in. Where do you think this puts you  in the Heisman race?
Joe hates this question. We go to the screen.
(uncomfortable) I really have no idea. That's up to  you guys.
The image changes to ESPN anchor CHRIS BERMAN in the stud

Now let's turn to our Heisman watch. (does the pose while  remaining seated) We begin with Sports Illustrated  cover boy Joe Kane of E.S.U. who led  his team to an impressive victory  this afternoon. Well, if Joe continues  to raise Kane, he may well be Able  to dust off a large space on his  trophy shelf. Although the real test  will come in four weeks against  Michigan and their Heisman hopeful,  Tim Waymen.
Joe walks across campus, headed for Camille's dorm.
Michigan also won big today. Timothy,  "He Could Go All The Way Men", will  be looking to do so against the  Timberwolves. And of course the able  Kane will be looking to also. I can't  wait.
Joe comes down the hall, knocks on Camille's door. No ans Knocks again. Nothing. Disappointed, he turns and walks a
The post-game victory party is in full swing. All the pla their girls and various groupies, dancing, drinking,  celebrating. Bud Lite and Joe stand drinking beer, watchi the action.
I don't know, I never seem to make  out at things like this.
Bobby, who's overheard this, walks by with Louanne.

sitting across the room with Alvin but his attention is o Autumn and Ray out on the dance floor. Alvin notices.
Forget it, nigger. No chance for you  there.

Griffin's goin' to medical school.  She likes that light-skinned  respectable shit. You're just her  ghetto toy.
Darnell challenged by this, gets up and goes over to wher Ray and Autumn are standing. A slow tune plays.
(to Autumn) Can I have this one?
I don't think so.

Autumn realizes this could quickly get out of hand.
(turning to Ray) Just one.

Ray reluctantly backs off. Darnell and Autumn start to da Several players who've picked up on the tension, watch th as they move around the floor. They try to pretend they'r just having a nice little chat.
(whispering) Take it easy, Darnell. This isn't a  good time to push things. You're  putting me in an awkward position.
Yeh, well, I got a little  encouragement along the way.
That kiss... it was just... a kiss.

Bullshit. You meant it. I wouldn't  be standing here now, everybody  thinkin' I'm a stupid asshole, if I  didn't know you meant it. I wanna  see you, Autumn. Not in study hall.  Not like your student. Like somebody  to be taken seriously.
I do take you seriously, Darnell,  but I'm still with Ray. I can't just  go paradin' around town.
I don't need to go paradin'. We'll  go someplace different. Someplace  nobody'll see us.
She looks at him a long beat. She doesn't need this  complication, this conflict, but she can't say no.
God, why am I even considering this?
The song ends. Ray moves in to reclaim her.
(to Darnell) All caught up on your arithmetic?
Darnell, pissed, gives Ray a shove.
Yeh, you only gained 37 yards on 12  carries.
Ray lunges back at him, but quickly several players, led Joe and Bud Lite, step between them. Darnell shrugs them and leaves the party.
(to Bud Lite) Just what we need, a little team  unity.
Ray takes Autumn's arm, pulls her out onto the patio.
I'm gettin' a little sick of this  asshole, Autumn. I don't like you  hangin' out with him. It's  embarrassing.
I don't hang out with him. I tutor  him.
Then have him get another tutor.
I can't do that. I made a commitment  to help him pass his qualifying exam.  I can't bail out on him now.

What the hell difference does it  makes? They'll grease him through no  matter what he does. Nobody's ever  gonna see his graduation. Don't tell  me you're falling for this guy. He's  just another gang-banger with speed.
I just said I wanted to help him.  What are you more afraid of, losing  your girl or your position?
Maybe you oughta think about what  you're in danger of losing.
Maybe I will.

Darnell sits alone on a bench under an old Willow, just  staring out at the night. He hears a voice behind him.
So where you wanna go?
He turns. It's Autumn.
The party's still in full gear. Ray is now chatting up a of the groupies. Joe and Bud Lite sit off in a corner. Jo knocked back several beers. He's a little tipsy, and lost thought.
Maybe she's out with some guy.
Who? Camille? I don't think she's  the type to screw around on ya. Shoot  ya, maybe...
It wouldn't be screwing around. It's  not like we're going together.
Joe's gaze falls on a sultry brunette, SHERI, at a table  across the way. She's eyeing Joe big time. She wants him. stares back at her. She doesn't blink.

Camille, carrying an armload of books, comes down the lib steps, having been studying late. As she heads for her do she sees Joe and Sheri going across the Quad; Sheri drape around Joe, nuzzling him. Joe looks over, spots Camille, stops; surprised, embarras to see her. They exchange a look. Camille, upset, turns a wheels off. Joe wants to say something to her, but can't it out.
We don't know where yet, but they seem to be slipping and sliding, clutching on to each other.
You're right, nobody would ever see  us here.
Near closing time. Darnell and Autumn lurch and stumble a the ice, collapsing against the boards now and then. Ther are few other skaters at this hour.
Yes, I figure the key is to go places  only white people go. Next time we'll  go bowling.
Autumn laughs, as the house lights start to blink, indica it's closing time.
Plus I saw this in Rocky. I never  believed a guy who was supposed to  be an athlete would skate that bad,  but now I know.
They make their way to an opening in the boards, stumble  over to a bench, begin to unlace.
Thanks, that was fun, sort of.
You were pretty good for the first  time.
Well, it's not really my first time.  My dad took me skating once.
He used to play ball for E.S.U.,  didn't he?
Yeah, how'd you know that?
I saw his picture on the Wall of  Fame. You got his eyes. Luckily, you  didn't get his thighs.
She laughs, looks at him a beat, starts to come forward t kiss him. He puts a finger to her lips.
Make sure you mean it this time.
She hesitates a beat, then comes forward again. They fall into a deep kiss. We PULL BACK to LONGSHOT. Two people al in the expanse of the ice rink. The lights flicker and go out.

Camille, unable to sleep, enters in her workout clothes.  Languid, melancholy, she goes to the treadmill, as Joe co out of the steam room with nothing but a towel around his waist. Both are surprised to see the other.
What are you doin' here?
Couldn't sleep.
I was just sweatin' out some of the  beer.
Camille just nods. Long, silent pause.
I didn't go home with her. I thought  about it... but I didn't.
You drink too much.
Yeh.
He turns, starts toward the door.
Why didn't you?
Why didn't I what?
Go home with her?
I don't know... I guess I figured  maybe there was somethin' goin' on  between you and me.
Camille hesitates, not sure whether to believe him, then  gets off the bike and walks toward him.
Then why'd you pick her up in the  first place?
I was drunk... I needed some company.
(angry) Company? Yeh, I can see you havin' a  real far-ranging discussion with  Sheri.
I mean, ya know, physical company...  I was... I just needed to pounce on  somebody I guess.
Camille, really steamed now, snatches the towel from arou Joe's waist, leaving him naked.
Why can't you pounce on me? Aren't I  good enough to pounce on?
Camille snaps the towel at him, driving him back. Joe's  totally thrown by this reaction in her.
Well, you're more conservative...  classier... you're not that kinda  girl...
She snaps the towel again, backing him against the traini table.
(insulted) How do you know? You've never slept  with me.
She pounds on his chest, pushing him back on the table.

What makes you think she's such a  great ride? (climbing up on top  of him) I'm prettier, my legs are longer... (pulling down her  leotard) I've got better tits. (exasperated) Why would you go to her, when you  have me?
I didn't know I had you.
(softer, leaning close) Well you do.
He looks at her a beat, then pulls her mouth down to his. They fall into a long, white-hot kiss.
Joe and Camille are making love passionately, energetical Camille, still worked up, rolls up on top.
(between kisses) You shoulda looked for me at the  library, or don't you ever go there?
(rolling back on top) I go there. I got a 3.2 in Political  Science. I just don't go there on  Saturday nights.
(rolling back on top  again) I have a paper due Monday. What'de  she do? Sit on your lap or just give  you the nail-me stare?
Shut up, Camille.
Joe rolls back on top, the momentum carrying both of them off the table and out of sight.
Some 100 students are taking a history test in blue books T.A., checking attendance, walks up to Louanne. She's une as the T.A. checks his chart.
What's your name?
Bobby Collins.
Can I see your I.D.?
Louanne knows she's in deep trouble.

A high-tech room full of video machines and monitors used run simultaneous views of different positions during the  same play. A grim-looking group of assistant coaches  approaches Winters as he runs through and reprograms the  images on the screen.
Coach, we, ah... got a problem with  Bobby Collins.
Yeh...
He talked... a friend... into taking  a test for him and got caught. They  had a new T.A. in there...
What's the penalty?
Well, the rules say automatic  expulsion for both of them.

Fortunately, we've got friends on  the Board of Regents. I think we can  beat this if we really go to bat for  him. We got Mack off when he turned  in that other guys term paper. (shaking his head) But what kinda idiot would do  something like that?
Well, I guess Bobby figured he was  gonna flunk...
I don't mean Bobby. I mean what kinda  guy would be dumb enough to take a  test for him?
Uh, well... it wasn't a guy.
A girl? Typical Collins. He must  have banged her until she couldn't  think straight. Who was it?
(barely able to get  it out) It was... Louanne.
Winters' face goes dead.
Winters, enraged, is venting his spleen at Louanne.
Jesus, Louanne, how could you be so  stupid?
I... he was behind, he needed help.  I'm sorry. I just...

Sorry! You're sorry! You've destroyed  my credibility at the University, my  authority with the players... Christ,  it looks like I'm running a dirty  program. And Collins of all people!  What the hell's the matter with you,  Louanne?
(crying) I don't know... I thought he... loved  me...

Loved you? He loves anything that  winks back, the little rat bastard.  And what are you gonna do for school  now? I use my influence to get you  back in, it'll stink to high hell.  The press'll crucify me.
I'll get in someplace.
God, Louanne, I told you to stay  away from my players. That was my  cardinal rule, stay away from the  damn players...
They've always been good enough for  you. Good enough to devote your life  to. Why aren't they good enough for  me? Or are they too good?
You're changing the subject, Louanne.  We're talkin' about you breakin' the  rules.
Didn't you ever break the rules just  a little? Didn't you tell me once  that 90 per cent of the schools obey  the NCAA rules, and the other 10 per  cent go to bowl games? Was that just  a joke?
She gets up and walks out of the room. Winters closes his eyes and slumps down on the couch.
Darnell sits at his table waiting for Autumn. Autumn stor in, obviously upset about something. She slaps a correcte test down in front of him.

Whatever you say, Teach. (big grin) I don't wish to be cast in a  pejorative light, so I'm dedicating  myself to achieving on a level more  commensurate with my abilities.
She shakes her head and walks away. Darnell's grin fades. looks at his test, a hint of tears in his eyes. He's  embarrassed and deeply worried.

The players are dressing for Monday practice, but it's  strangely subdued. Bobby Collins opens his locker to find BULLET-RIDDLED PRACTICE JERSEY hanging inside. Immediatel the rest of the players burst into raucous laughter.

Suddenly the room goes silent. Standing in the doorway is Coach Winters. He says nothing, looks around the room, the players avoid his gaze. His eyes come to rest on Bobby. Bobby tries to  hide the shirt, but Winters has seen. Winters just stares Bobby a beat, then.
You all played a fine game on  Saturday. Take the day off.
With that, he turns and walks out the door. The players r silent. Bobby throws the shirt in the trash.

Winters walks in the front door, past the desk, up the st and down the hall to his daughter's room. She's packing h things. He goes over to her, takes her in his arms and hu her tight. Neither speak. A tear rolls down Louanne's che Hits the floor.
A very nervous Bobby Collins comes down the hall and knoc on Coach Winter's door.
C'mon in, Collins.
Bobby enters and stands across from Winters' desk. Winter doesn't invite him to sit.
Listen, Coach, I just want you to  know I'm really sorry about this  whole thing with Louanne. I was real  glad to hear she's gonna be goin' to  junior college here...
(cutting him off) Shut up.
Bobby does. Instantly.

I could easily take your case to the  Board of Regents. You've had no prior  infractions and I could argue that  you were under abnormal pressure. (pause) But I won't. You embarrassed me, you  embarrassed my family, you embarrassed  the program. As of now, you are no  longer a member of this university  or it's football team. Clean out  your locker.
Bobby just stands there a beat, in confusion and disbelie There is no wavering, no sympathy in Winters' eyes. Final dazed and disoriented, Bobby turns and walks out.

Joe is posed in front of the school library, one of it's  more photogenic buildings. T.V. sportscaster LYNN SWANN a his video crew wait to interview him as a MAKEUP GIRL fin applying makeup to Joe's face. Publicist Sharon Braver wa like a hawk.

Joe, this game is being billed as a  potential "Heisman Shootout". Did  you feel any added pressure this  week...
A phalanx of photographers crowd around, snapping away as Joe goes through passing drills.
...knowing that you're going head to  head with Heisman rival, Tim Waymen?
Well, ya know, you try to block it  out, but it's basically impossible...  Everybody seems to be talkin' about  it, all the newspapers, the  interviews...
Joe is being interviewed by DALLAS PERRY on a local telev show.
The hype on T.V., tryin' to get  somethin' goin...
Sharon Braver steps directly in front of the video camera waves off the take.
Hold it! Hold it!
What?! What's the problem?
Braver takes Joe aside, talks to him confidentially.

Joe and Camille are sharing a pizza, but not alone. A vid spotlight shines on them, as yet another crew rolls tape.

Joe nods and heads back in front of the camera.
(to Braver, irritated) We all set now? (gets a nod) Let's mark it. (the take is marked) Joe, this game is being billed as a  potential "Heisman Shootout."

A huge bonfire burns, as a large segment of the student b has gathered in front of the Timberwolf statue. The  cheerleaders, all wearing "KANE IS ABLE" buttons, whip th crowd up, as Joe is introduced on the podium.
Did you feel any added pressure this  week, knowing that you're going head  to head with Heisman rival, Tim  Waymen?
The cheerleaders begin to chant, "Let's go, Joe." On "Joe they assume the Heisman trophy pose. Joe seems slightly  embarrassed by it all.
No, I don't really think too much  about that kinda thing.
Swann shoots Braver a poisonous look.
Joe and Camille sit on a bank looking down at the railroa tracks below. Neither says anything. Joe seems strangely  preoccupied. Camille decides to break the silence.
Your parents comin' to the game  tomorrow?
My mom's dead. My dad has never seen  me play.
Why not?
Guess he's not that interested in  football.
But you're one of the best players  in the country.
(snapping) He's just not into it, o.k.?
(chastised) O.k. (silence) What's goin' on, Joe? You ask me out  here, like you wanta talk about  somethin', then you don't say  anything. You worried about tomorrow?
No... I'm worried about the days  after that. I just. I don't know...  I feel like tomorrow's gonna be my  last game. I want to stay up, make  the time go slow.
Why would it be your last game? You  afraid of getting hurt?
No, that'd be a relief. Then, at  least, I wouldn't be a failure.
Joe, why are you thinking like this?  Why would you be a failure? You're  having a great year, you're a Heisman  Trophy candidate, you got millions  of dollars waiting for you in the  pros.
(testy) How do you know what's waiting for  me? You don't know me at all.
(hurt) I don't know you? How can you say  that?
Because you wouldn't be here now if  you did. You only know the guy that's  supposed to make millions in the  pros.
Is that what you think? That I'm  with you for the money?
Why else?
Infuriated, she slaps him across the face.
Fuck you, Joe. (starting to cry) I don't give a shit about your money.  I don't even give a shit about  football. And you know what? Maybe  you're right, maybe I don't know  you.

She turns and storms away up the hill, as we hear a TRAIN WHISTLE. Joe watches her go, then starts down the hill to the tracks as the train comes into view. Camille stops, turns back, sees Joe headed for the tracks starts to worry. Joe reaches the grade and steps into the middle of the tr facing the oncoming train. Horrified, Camille runs down t embankment toward him.
Joe! Joe! My god, Joe, what are you  doing? No! No!

As the train approaches, it's horn blaring, Joe lies face down on the tracks, his hands gripping the railroad ties. Camille arrives at the bottom of the hill in time to see train race over him. She falls to her knees screaming. Under the train, we see Joe desperately hugging the groun head down, toes dug in, hands clutching the ties. It's li a tornado under there, dirt debris flying everywhere, his clothes flapping wildly. The train passes. Camille looks up, afraid to breath as J lies motionless on the tracks. Suddenly he stirs, pushes  himself up to his knees. She lets out a scream of joy, ra toward him, as he gets to his feet, stumbles off the grad She hugs him to her, tears streaming down her face, helps him over to the embankment.
God Joe, oh god, are you allright?
(drained) Yeh, just got some dirt in my teeth.  Guess you've really seen the dark  side now, huh? You should've gotten  out while you had the chance. Before  it all goes to hell.
I don't wanta get out, damnit. What's  wrong Joe? Why would it all go to  hell?

I'm a Kane, Camille. That's all it  takes. We're cut out to be drunks  and fuck-ups. We never live up to  expectations. It's in our blood. My  dad, brothers, uncles -- we all drink  and sooner or later we all fuck up.  My dad went the longest. Waited till  he was playin' triple A ball, before  he hit the wall. Sometimes I feel  like I'm just waiting for my turn.  The better I do, the closer it gets.
You're not like them, you can beat  all that. You can stop drinking, you  can break the chain.
If I gave up that, I wouldn't be  much of a football player. And if I  wasn't a football player, what would  I be?
The question hangs in the air.
You'de still be Joe. And I'd still  love you.
He pulls her to him, kisses her hair, they slump against  each other.
Just don't say I never warned you.
STEVE ZABRISKIE and BO SCHEMBECKLER in the foreground, th jammed to capacity stadium in the background. This shot i going out on nationwide T.V., the college Game of the Wee

Joe brings the offense to the line of scrimmage. Yells  signals.

Joe fades to pass, looks right, looks left, can't find a  receiver, decides to run for it. He sprints up the middle 15, 10; a SAFETY comes at him at the 5. We see Joe's P.O.V. through HELMETCAM. Joe lies motionless as his teamates run over to him.
He's still down. Looks like he's  hurt.
We go to Winters, worried on the sideline, as the celebra around him begins to die down.

Four.

Yeh, you're the little bastard.  Account of you, my bros' datin' his  cell mate. You hear me, powderpuff?  Gonna make you pay. You gonna be my  cellmate now. You gonna have 250  lbs. of pissed-off nigger up your  ass.
E.S.U. in an eight-man line looking  for the run on third and short.

Waymen fakes to Simms, Mack on the  blitz, Waymen is goin for it all!  Hit as he throws.

The ball, however, flies through the air, a perfect spira The E.S.U. secondary has been fooled by the play fake and a step behind. The ball comes down in the hands of the  Michigan tight end, JERRY HUNT.
Hunt has got a step. He's got it!  Touchdown!
Winters slams his headphones to the ground.
Great clutch throw under pressure.  Can't do it much better than that.
The Doctor examines Joe, shines a light in his eyes, make him track his finger, etc.
You're vision's back to normal.
You think you can go?

Damn tough to scare that little white  boy. Either his momma dropped him on  his head, or the motherfucker is  deaf.
Coach Winters goes to Darnell.
Jefferson, in for Griffen.
Griffen slams his helmet to the ground.
Joe breaks the huddle as the E.S.U. offense comes to the  line.
Ball on the Michigan 47, 1:02 to go,  Kane brings 'em to the line of  scrimmage.

Joe fades to pass once again, lets the rush come, then fl out a screen pass to Darnell. Darnell grabs it and takes  off, slipping tackles, cutting back, juking. Darnell fina runs out of bounds at the twenty.
Great run by Jefferson, the highly- touted Freshman, the longest of the  day for the Wolves. And this one is  turning out to be everything we  thought it would be.
coming back to the huddle, pumped up. Joe kneels in the  center.
O.K., time to put the women and  children to bed, and go looking for  dinner.
He begins to howl, as do all the others. The Call of the  Wild.
82 Strike, Eagle, Crown, on 2.

They clap hands, come to the line. Joe looks over the def bends under center and barks signals, The ball is snapped Action goes to SLOW MOTION. Joe fakes to Darnell, fades to pass. Kane looking for Jefferson. It's...  Intercepted! Intercepted by Freeman!  And that should do it.

Steve Zabriskie is doing the wrap-up, the emptying stadiu behind him.
Well, it was everything we expected  it to be. Fine performances on both  sides of the field.
Players undress and shower in relative silence. No joy he

The edge in the much ballyhooed battle  of the quarterbacks would probably  have to go to Michigan's Tim Waymen  who threw for 2 touchdowns, and ran  for another. Joe Kane accounted for  three E.S.U. touchdowns, but had  that crucial interception in the  waning moments. And that proved to  be the difference.
The door of the locker room opens, and a flood of reporte enter. Joe hides back in the showers, leaning his forehea against the wall, the water coursing over him.
Darnell comes out of the locker room, having showered and dressed. He's surprised to see Autumn and her father talk to Coach Humes.
Hey, Autumn.
Hi, Darnell.
Is this your dad?
Yes...
How do you do, Mr. Haley. I'm Darnell  Jefferson.
Jefferson? Nice run you made on that  screen pass. Another block and you  might have scored.
Thank you. We'll get 'em next year.
How do you and Autumn know each other?  You a friend of Ray's?
Darnell is jolted by this question. It's obvious that Aut has never told her dad about him.
(filling the void) Ah, I tutor him...
Oh really? In what?
Darnell would like to crawl under a rock.
Math and English.
Ah.
There's a slight tone of condescension in Mr. Haley's voi He realizes Darnell hasn't passed his entrance exam. This not lost on Darnell.
Well, stay on top of that, Darnell.  I'd have been in real trouble if I  hadn't gotten my degree. I played  ball once. Hurt my knee.
Yeh, I know...
I used to put a copy of my report  card inside the webbing of my helmet  to remind me that college was more  important than football.
(forcing enthusiasm) Good idea. Well, I gotta get goin'.  Nice to meet you Mr. Haley.
Nice to meet you, Darnell.
See you around, Autumn.
Before Autumn can respond, Ray Griffen approaches from th other direction.
Hey, Mr. Haley. Good to see you.
Hey, Ray. You still havin' dinner  with us tonight?
Darnell embarrassed and humiliated, hears all this as he  walks away. Autumn wants to go explain, but can't in fron of her father.
The post-game party. Not as raucous as after the opening  game victory. A few players are dancing, but most are sit drinking, commiserating.
