Not yet. Probably out with Camille.  Haven't seen Darnell either.
Lattimer's sitting on the bed with a coed named LESLIE.  They're kissing softly, light necking. Lattimer starts to unbutton her blouse. She begins to demur.
I think we better get back downstairs.
No, Leslie, we're just getting to  know each other.
(starting to get up) No, I think...
Lattimer grabs her arm roughly, pulls her back to the bed She's starting to get a little scared.
C'mon Leslie, you didn't come up  here to stop now.
He tries to kiss her again, she pushes him away, starts f the door. Angered, that steroid pump in his eyes, he grab her again, throws her violently on the bed. She screams.
What were you doin'? Leadin' me on?

He gets on the bed, kneels above her. She starts to strug He slaps her across the face, rips her blouse open. Freak she begins to scream and kick. Enraged, Lattimer slaps he around, picks her up, shakes her like a rag doll, slaps h some more, throws her to the floor. Picks her up again, w suddenly the door BURSTS OPEN and Bud Lite and Alvin race in.
(throwing Leslie on  the bed again) Get outa here!

Bud Lite and Alvin charge Lattimer, try to wrestle him do but his hormone level is so high, he fights like a bull. other players charge in and finally all four are able to  shackle Lattimer. He continues to struggle a bit, then gi up, a panting, sweating, shaking hulk.
This is it, man. No more 'roids.  This shit has gotta stop.
Lattimer breaks down and cries.

Joe lies on his bed, a bottle of vodka next to his coca-c He stares at the larger than life cardboard stand-up of  himself. He takes a drink, then gets up and grabs his jac The phone rings. He looks at it a beat, then walks out of the room.
Camille's on the phone, waiting, the one calling Joe. She listens a few more rings, hangs up, concerned.
Winters sits at the main console replaying the game-endin interception over and over. The phone rings.
Hello, yeh... What?!
The rest of the locker room is dark except for the light in Winters' office. All the assistant coaches are there.
It looks like this will blow over.  The girl's father is a big booster,  contributed a lotta money. So he  said they won't go to the press.
He said that? The father?
Yeh, he's not exactly happy about  all this, but he doesn't wanta hurt  the program.
We're still gonna have to suspend  Lattimer.
What for? There aren't any charges.  Nobody outside the program knows  about this.
He's outa control, Lyle. We can't  ignore this anymore. I don't know  what pisses me off more -- that he's  juicin' or that he's doin' such a  shitty job of hidin' it.
He's never tested positive. If we  suspend him without proof, he could  sue us for jeopardizing his draft  status, his pro career.

Yeh, but we can't sit and wait till  he kills somebody. I hate to lose  him as much as you do, but we gotta  clean him up before he does somethin'  that lands the whole program on  probation. Plus, we have to take  some action or the girl's dad is  gonna start havin' second thoughts.  I don't care how many checks he's  written.
So what do we do?
All eyes go to Winters.
Bring him down here.
Close on a contrite, but shaken Steve Lattimer.
Three games? Why so many?
You oughta be grateful I didn't  suspend you for the whole year.
Lattimer nods, he knows it's true.
What are you gonna give as the reason?
We'll say you've got a hamstring  pull.
(relieved) Thank you, Coach.

Don't thank me. During those three  weeks, you better kick the roids,  cause when you come back I'm gonna  personally test you before every  game. No N.C.A.A. shit either. I'm  gonna watch the piss go into the  bottle. You got that?
(barely audible, shamed) Yes, sir.
Start practicing your limp.

Not the 911 we saw earlier. Joe sits at a table in the ba with Darnell, drinking tequila with a beer chaser. Both a down in the dumps. At a nearby table there's a group of  TOWNIES and their GIRLFRIENDS.
Coupla real college heroes, huh?  Tearin' up the town.
First time I ever lost a girl and a  game on the same day. Guess I never  really had the girl.
Joe looks up to see one of the townies' girls, DEBBIE, gi him the once over and a little smile. Joe smiles back, no really interested. Debbie's BOYFRIEND notices.
You know that guy?
Not really...
Then why you smilin' at him?
I don't know... he looks like that  E.S.U. quarterback guy. Joe, what's  his name?
So what? So you go and smile at him?
The boyfriend, drunk and looking for trouble, goes over t Joe's table.
You been lookin' at my girlfriend?
(a little drunk himself) I don't know. Which one is she?
Wise guy, huh? Mr. bigtime  quarterback. The one who choked his  ass off today. You got nothin' better  to do then look at my girlfriend?
Joe says nothing.
Hey, Heisman, I'm talkin' to you.  You too good to talk to me?
I'm not even interested in talkin'  to you.
You think you're a bad ass? You think  my girl's hot for you? Take your  pads off, you're just another pussy.

Joe gets up to go. The boyfriend grabs him, Joe pushes hi away. The guy charges Joe. The bar owner rushes to the ph as a full scale brawl begins. Joe takes a blow, knocks th boyfriend back into a table, knocking beer bottles to the floor. The boyfriend falls on one, opening a deep gash in his shoulder.
(grabbing him) C'mon we gotta get outa here.
A speeding car goes by us, weaving, crossing the yellow l on the curves.
Joe's driving, Darnell's holding on. Suddenly we hear SIR Joe sees flashing lights in the rear-view mirror.
Oh shit...
Winters is asleep. The phone rings. He picks it up.
What is it now?... Oh Jesus...
Joe sits across the desk from Winters, just the two of th
The guy went for me first. What was  I supposed to do?

Doesn't make any difference. It made  the papers, all the wire services.  The guy had to go to the hospital.  Worst of all they got you on drunk  driving. You had a blood alcohol  level .50 above the legal limit. We  can't smooth that over, Joe. It'd  look like we were sprayin' Pledge on  bird shit. We had to agree to send  you to Rehab.
Rehab? I'll be a god-damn joke. You  can't do this to me.
It was the only way we could get  them to drop the assault and D.W.I.  You go to trial on those, we lose  you for a year, and risk NCAA  investigation. C'mon, lotsa athletes  have been through Rehab.
Not in the middle of the season. Not  in the middle of a Heisman campaign.
You'll only miss four games. You'll  be back in time for the last one,  Georgia Tech, and a Bowl if we get  there. Plus, you've still got your  senior year.
Yeh, but what will I come back as?  What kinda player?
Don't worry, you'll still be the  Man. You'll still be the leader of  this team.
Joe doesn't believe it, but he manages a nod, as he gets to leave.
I'm sorry, Coach.
These things happen.
Joe walks on out, Winters watches him go, then slams the  desk in anger. Drained, he sinks back in his chair.
Fuckin' kids.
Darnell's walking across campus toward class. Autumn sees him, calls out to him.
Darnell, wait. C'mon Darnell, I wanta  talk to you.
Darnell doesn't slow up. Autumn has to run to catch up.
Where you been, I been callin' you?
Been busy.
Darnell, I'm sorry about Saturday.  It was an awkward situation.
It wasn't awkward. It was educational.  I realized how you see me. I'm good  enough to tutor, to go places with,  but not to tell your father about.
That's not it. It's just that my  father expects me to be with somebody  like Ray. He wouldn't understand us.
(stopping) Why not?
I don't know... he likes Ray cause...
He's a good student, he acts right...  he doesn't need football. He's class  and I'm not, right?
I didn't say that.
You don't have to, Autumn. I'm  everything your dad used to be and  don't want you fallin' back into.
Darnell...
You were right before, Autumn. I  should have another tutor. Thanks  for everything you did for me.
Darnell walks away. Autumn can only watch him go.

Joe finishes packing his bags. He sees a picture of Camil on the dresser. Picks it up, looks at it a beat, drops it the trash. He carries his Heisman cardboard standup into shower, pulls out a match and lights it. He watches it ca fire, then grabs his suitcase and walks out of the room. hold on the burning standup, as flames lick at Joe's smil
Joe is shown into his room. Bare. One cot. One dresser. H drops his bag, sags onto the bed.
Four fuckin' weeks?
A tired and depressed group of E.S.U. football players un after practice. Bud and Alvin sit in their pads, Lattimer standing in street clothes. Bud softly sings "Don't Cry F Me Argentina."
Shit, the defense is gonna have to  pitch shutouts now... (to Lattimer) and you're gone for 3. What the hell  did you take that shit for?
Nobody seemed to mind when I was  knockin' people's dicks in the dirt.
I bust chops too. I don't have to  get all fucked up.
Not everybody has the ability you  do, Alvin. You do what you have to  do to play.
Well, you're not playin' much now  are you? Shit, whole fuckin' season  down the drain.
Winters and Galen Howard are walking across the field aft practice. The stadium is deserted.
I been talkin' to Chancellor Wilson...
What's he wanta do now, cut practice  down to once a week?
No, he's happy with the way the  season's gone so far. The Alumni  have pretty much stayed off his back,  but with Joe out now, it could all  be up for grabs again.
He thinks he's gonna have trouble  marchin' the ball down the old fund- raisin' board, huh?
The facts are, all we have left are  freshman quarterbacks, and nothin' I  saw at practice today, convinced me  that any of them are ready to step  in.
What are you sayin?
We gotta get Bobby Collins back.
Wilson say that?
He didn't have to.
Forget it, Galen, Collins is no All- Star either.
Yeh, but he's good enough to get us  a split of the next four games.
Look, just because you're Wilson's  boy all of a sudden, doesn't mean  I'm gonna let him make me look like  a fuckin' whore.

Don't give me that high and mighty  shit. There's a lotta people on the  bubble here. Four straight loses and  we're out of bowl contention. How's  that gonna make you look? If you're  too stupid to consider your own  situation, then maybe you oughta  think about your assistant coaches.  They've got families to feed too.
Howard walks away, pissed off, leaving Winters alone in t middle of the field.

The seven members of the BOARD OF REGENTS sit on one side a long rectangular table, the Chairman in the middle. On other side are coach Winters, Bobby Collins, the Presiden of the Faculty Senate, EDWARD LEARNIHAN, Academic Advisor ARTHUR SHANE, President of the Student Body, RICHARD FOWL and Galen Howard. Fowler is addressing the board.

Therefore, I respectfully submit  that Bobby Collins should not be  given special treatment just because  he's a football player. Would a  regular student get a reinstatement  hearing if they'de been caught  cheating? Nobody's talking about  letting the girl who took the test  back in.
Winters could kill this kid.
I think it's also instructive to  look at some of the courses this  young man has taken. Beginning Golf,  Voice and Speech Improvement...
I'd like to point out that Mr. Collins  was still on schedule to get his  degree.
(pointing to Collin's  transcript) In what, Swimming Pool Management?
Would you like to respond, Coach  Winters?
Winters rises, sweating, less from nervousness than from odious nature of what he has to do.

I don't know much about all this  other stuff, but I do know the  punishment should fit the crime.  Cheating's bad, but I don't think it  deserves a life sentence. Here's one  of those athletes who takes college  level courses, who wants to graduate.  I think Bobby Collins made a big  mistake, but he's already been  suspended for several weeks. He's  served his time. I think he deserves  a second chance.

Like Alvin Mack? We gave him a second  chance and since he's had 5  incompletes, 4 withdrawals and still  reads at a fourth grade level. You're  using his body to make money for the  Athletic Department -- you, yourself,  are making three times what the  Chancellor is -- but obviously no  one is making an effort to see that  this kid gets an education.
He's helpin' to pay for your physics  lab too. If you're willin' to go  without a new office, maybe I could  hold him out a few games. Save his  body.
Gentlemen...
Alvin was way behind in school when  he got here. You can't make up for,  in four years, what it took 18 to  create.
Then he should never have been  admitted in the first place. It's  not fair to other students who worked  hard to get here.
Is it fair to exclude kids who come  from inferior schools? You hold  everybody to the same standards,  you're discriminating against the  poor kids.
Most of my players are farm boys,  inner-city kids. Football is their  deliverance.
Deliverance from what? A valid  education?
You throw Bobby Collins and Alvin  out, you take away their futures. In  Alvin's case you probably cost him a  couple million dollars in the pros.
But this is not a football vocational  school. It's an Institute of Higher  Learning.
Yeh, but when was the last time 80,000  people showed up to watch a kid do a  chemistry experiment?

Gentlemen, please, let's get back to  the business at hand, Bobby Collins.  As you know, I played football here.  And I remember how hard it was to  practice and then study when you're  dead tired. So I have some sympathy  for this young man. But I never  cheated, so the real question is his  character. Since you know him better  than anyone else in this room; and  having talked to him and observed  him over the last several weeks, do  you feel he's learned his lesson? In  other words, can you vouch for his  character?
Winters would rather cut off his own head with a razor bl
(it's killing him) Yes, sir, I can.
Bobby Collins breaks into a wide, triumphant smile.
Learnihan and Winters come down the steps, their faces se As they split off:
Another case like this, I'll take it  all the way up to the Governor.
Don't mess with me, Learnihan. I'll  have you teachin' Study Hall.
Bobby Collins walks in prior to practice. His teammates g round, slap him on the back, high five etc. Winters watch from his office, disgusted.

Coach Winters is in his video alcove watching footage of upcoming opponent -- it's like he's looking through it th his mind elsewhere, something boiling up inside him. Sudd he smashes his fist into the screen, breaking it into pie His hand bleeds. He doesn't care. He just sits there and  seethes.
Camille's on the phone.
Hello, my name is Camille Schaeffer.  I'd like to speak to Joe Kane.
Joe is aimlessly flipping cards toward a wastebasket. A N knocks on his door.
You've got a phone call. A Camille  Schaeffer.
Joe says nothing, not wanting to deal with this.
She says she's your girlfriend
I don't want to talk to her.
You sure?
Yeh.
The nurse leaves. Joe gets up, goes to the wall, and star pounding it with his right hand.
I'm sorry, he doesn't wish to speak  to you right now.
Crushed and angry, Camille hangs up.
Bud Lite is watching television. Louanne enters on her wa to Bobby Collins' room, carrying an armload of neatly-pre laundry. But Lite gets up to bar her way.
Hey, Louanne, how ya' doin?
Fine, Bud, ya know. Goin to J.C.,  hopin' to get back in here next year.  Just came by to give Bobby some  laundry I did for him.
You two seein' each other again?
Yeh, he was even talking about us  gettin' a place off campus together,  until he got reinstated. I don't  know how I woulda told my dad.
Bud just nods blankly. Louanne starts to head for Bobby's room.
Ah, Louanne... (pained to say it) I wouldn't go in there right now.
Why not?
Bud doesn't have the heart to tell her. She finally reali Bobby's with another girl.
Ah. Guess I'm pretty stupid when it  comes to men. I never learn, do I?
I think maybe men are just stupid  when it comes to you. If you ever  feel like, ya know, just talkin'  sometime, gettin' a beer -- let me  know. My schedule's pretty open.
Thanks, Bud (handing him the  clothes) Give him these, will ya?
Bud nods. Louanne, fighting back tears, walks back down t hall with as much dignity as she can muster.
Winters comes to the door, hesitates, walks in and finds huddled on his bed. Shivering.
Get up. I wanta talk to you.
Joe looks resentful but makes an effort and sits up.
Don't sit up. Stand up. If you can.
Joe gets unsteadily to his feet. He feels sick. Winters  reaches out to shake hands. Joe does not reciprocate. Hid his right hand behind his body.

What's the matter, Joe? You won't  shake hands with me. (Joe is silent) You don't want me to see your hand,  do you? (more silence) So I guess what I heard was true,  huh? You been poundin' the walls  with your passin' hand, right? (silence) I tell you what, Joe, you want to  hit somethin', hit me.
Joe doesn't move.
I said hit me. I'm the one who put  you in here. Don't hit the damn wall.  It ain't the wall's fault. Hit me!  Go on, hit me right now!
Joe is angry but he doesn't want to do anything about it.

Who else you wanta hit, huh? you're  daddy maybe? Cause he's a no-show  prick? Well, I'm a daddy, too, and  not a very good one at that. So just  hit me instead! I'll take your daddy's  beatin' for him. Go on, you want to.  Hit me, damnit!
Joe shakes his head.
(pushes Joe in the  chest) Hit me! I'm not gonna leave you alone  until you hit me. (shakes Joe by  shoulders) The guys'll thank you. They've always  wanted to do it. So do it now, damnit!  Do it!
Joe sinks to his knees. Winters stares down at him, then  kneels also, his own anger and frustration draining away.
O.K., Joe, it's o.k. I guess I need  it more than you do. (pause) You gotta quit beatin' up on yourself.  Let me see that hand.
Joe reveals his hand. It's barked and cut, but not badly  swollen.

It's o.k. (playfully) You can still throw with it, you  fuckin' mook. (pause) Look, the nurses say this is the  toughest time for you right now. I  thought I'd stick around a little,  case you wanta play some cards, pick  a fight with the wall again,  whatever...
You don't have to.
Yes I do.

Lattimer fills a bag with all his steroid paraphernalia. carries it to his bathroom where he slowly empties it int his toilet. Syringes, vials and bottles of pills all tumb into the water. He flushes.

The sun shines through the window. Joe wakes up, raises u looks over at Winters who is asleep in a chair. Winters  rouses. Joe gives him a little smile, he's allright. Wint gives him a nod of approval.

head_text.subj: MUSIC UP. BEGIN A SERIES OF SHOTS

text: detailing the Timberwolves progress over the next four ga
1) Players shaking hands at midfield after the game. The  scoreboard reads E.S.U. 14 Boston College 10.
2) Darnell in study hall, with his new tutor concentratin on her explanation, applying himself.

3) Steve Lattimer, in street clothes, paces the sidelines jumping up and down in frustration, his hamstring bandage to sell the injury ruse. He catches himself, gets back on his crutches. A newspaper fades up through the shot. It r "Wolves Offense Fires Blanks in 13-0 Loss to Texas."

4) Darnell sits in a cafe, drinking coffee and studying. comes in, his arm around a co-ed, MONICA. They buy a past and leave, not having seen Darnell. Darnell ponders this second, goes back to studying.
5) A group of patients is gathered around a T.V. set in t Rehab Center, watching a pre-game show. One goes to Joe's room, where Joe's lying on his cot.
Hey, Joe, don't you wanta watch the  game? It's on cable.
No thanks.
Joe leans back, staring at the ceiling.
6) Sportscaster DALLAS PERRY is holding forth on the loca evening news.
E.S.U. on the strength of a 62 yard  touchdown run by freshman Darnell  Jefferson, squeaked by the North  Carolina Tarheels today, 14 to 13,  keeping their bowl hopes alive.

7) Darnell, with his books, on the way to the library, pa the frat house where the victory party is in progress. He sees Ray and Autumn walking together. Autumn sees him, he face lights up. He gives her a slight smile, keeps walkin She watches him with a certain longing.
8) Darnell, alone in the library, late at night, studying
9) Lattimer, carrying his gear bag, walks into the locker room. His teammates come over to shake his hand, slap him the back, welcome him back to the team.
Joe sits on his bed listening to the E.S.U. broadcast.
E.S.U. hoping to get past a tough  Iowa Hawkeyes team in their last  game before the return of star  quarterback, Joe Kane.
The E.S.U. defense is on the field. Alvin moves up opposi the OFFENSIVE GUARD.
I know you, motherfucker. You're the  prick who got my little sister  pregnant. We ain't seen you around  lately. Where you been, huh? Answer  me, motherfucker, or I'm gonna peel  your cap.
The ball is hiked. Iowa runs a sweep left. Lattimer tries get outside to contain, but is blocked by the fullback, w goes low and cuts his legs out from under him.
Shit, Lattimer...

Alvin pursues the play as the ballcarrier heads for the  corner, then suddenly cuts back. Alvin has overrun the pl slightly. We go to SLOW MOTION as he turns and is hit wit wicked CRACK-BACK BLOCK by the guard he taunted. Alvin's flexes at a horrifying angle. We HEAR THE SNAP of bone an tendon, as Alvin plummets to the ground, writhing in pain grabbing his left leg.
Oh, no...
The doctor and trainers sprint out to the field.
We move in on Joe's face, as Harvey is heard on the radio the b.g.
Oh, boy, this does not look good,  Harmon. They're bringing the  stretchers out...
Joe's eyes close. He knows what this means.
Alvin is being strapped on the stretcher.
(wailing in pain) Oh, shit, oh shit, I'll kill that  motherfucker. I'll... Oh shit...
An ambulance carrying Alvin emerges from the stadium. We  hear CHEERING inside, the SIREN outside.
Twelve seconds left, Iowa driving  for the winning touchdown. Fourth  and goal at the one. E.S.U. trying  to hold on without their star middle  linebacker, Alvin Mack.

The E.S.U. defensive line digs in. Lattimer tries to suck his remaining strength. Iowa runs a blast to Lattimer's side. He fights through o block, the ballcarrier coming right toward him. They meet a titanic collision at the goal line. The back keeps driv twisting. Lattimer tries to hold him, but weaker than he on steroids, is unable to. The back falls over the goal l Touchdown. IOWA 13 E.S.U. 10. As the Iowa players celebrate all around him, Lattimer si where he fell, a beaten and humiliated young man.
Coach, you've lost two of your last  four.
Coach Winters faces the press.
Why do your teams seem to nose dive  at the end of the last couple seasons?

This was a tough loss, but this ain't  any nose dive. We've had some key  players out, but if we win next week,  we'll still win the conference and  go to a major bowl on New Year's  Day. I mean, I know you guys can't  write, but I thought you could at  least count.
Alvin lies on a bed, his leg bandaged and elevated. He's  still a little groggy from anesthetic. Coach Winters stan beside him.
You look good, Alvin.
Yeh, I feel o.k.
Any of the guys been down yet?
They called.
Hell, you know how football players  are about hospitals and injuries.
Yeh.
Several beats of silence. Then:
I'm never gonna play again, am I?
Doctors aren't always right, Alvin...  but I just want you to know... you're  the best defensive football player I  ever coached.

Alvin nods. Winters comes forward, hugs him around the he gives him a smile, walks out. Tears brim in Winters eyes he leaves. Alvin's head goes back against the pillow. Tea aren't brimming here. They're rolling down his cheeks.
Joe walks out with his suitcase. Coach Winters waits for  him. Shakes his hand. They get in the car.
Congratulations. I'm proud of you,  Joe.
I know you had a difficult time.  Michigan is easy, right? Bourbon is  tough.
Scotch.
They share a laugh. Winters pulls out two sets of round t airline tickets.
I got somethin' for ya. Coupla round  trip tickets. Go see your dad. Get  it cleaned up.
Joe takes the tickets, just looks at him.
(on the phone) I'm gonna have to take a test with  the coach right there. You sure you  got somethin' better than blockers?
Much better. This guy is foolproof.  See ya Saturday.

Lattimer hangs up, picks up a HYPODERMIC. Stares at it a  second, sweat beading on his forehead. Then plunges it an inch deep into his thigh. Pulls it out, sits on the bed a beat, then picks up a barbell and begins to pump it furio biceps bulging.
The coach is facing Ray and Darnell across his desk.
I wanta do something different for  this game. Try to maximize our speed,  but keep you both in the lineup at  the same time. Ray, I'm moving you  to fullback. Darnell, you're startin'  at tail.
Ray is stunned, Darnell elated, but neither says a word.

Ray, you'll be carrying the ball  less and blocking more, but they'll  still have to respect your running  and pass-catching ability. Not  everybody can make a transition like  this. You think you can handle it?
(tight lipped) Yes, sir.
Good. We can't afford any hang dogs.
Camille comes off the court, after tennis practice. She's surprised to find Joe waiting for her.
Hello, Camille.
(cool) Hello, Joe. You allright now?
Yeh... yeh, I think so.
Good, I'm happy for you.
She starts to walk away, heading for the bike racks.
Camille, hold on, O.K.? I'm sorry  that I didn't want... that I couldn't  see you.
You couldn't even talk to me. What  happened to "there's somethin' goin'  on between you and me"?
Camille gets on her bike...
C'mon, Camille, I was embarrassed. I  couldn't...
and pedals off.
(shouting after her) I couldn't understand why anybody  would wanta talk to me. Camille!
She just keeps on going.

A bus comes up the hill toward us, on the main street of  Joe's sooty, little home town, the huge stacks of moribun steel works filling the sky in the background. The bus st at a corner. Joe steps off. No bag. He's not planning on  staying long.

Joe goes to the front door. Knocks, gets no answer, pushe the door open, walks through the messy, cluttered house t the back porch. Seated in a metal folding chair, smoking cigarette, looking out at the yard is Joe's DAD. He's got couple days growth of beard, and although not drunk now, has the look of one.
How ya doin', Dad?
(surprised to see him) Joe! What's this? They throw you  out?
No.
I heard about your little set-to.  They had it on the news here.
Yeh, they sent me to rehab.
We know what that's worth. Your  brother's been through it three times.
Joe nods sadly.
So what are you doin' here?
I've been thinking about some things,  Dad.
That's what that damn rehab'll do.  Make you think about a lotta things  you can't do nothing' about.
I kinda been wonderin' why you never  came to any of my games. All those  years.
Oh, I don't know. I guess I didn't  wanta make you nervous. You mighta  tried too hard and screwed up.
Or I mighta done real well. Which  woulda been harder on you, Dad?
(sensing the anger) What do you mean?
Mighta made you feel bad. Like maybe  it wasn't written someplace that we  all gotta go on our ass. Like maybe  you coulda done somethin' more, if  you'de tried a little harder.
Or maybe I didn't wanta see you  gettin' all excited, all pumped up  with pride, when I knew one day it  would all come crashin' down. Just  like it did.

I think I spent the last couple years  hopin' I'd die before that day. But  you know what Dad? That day came and  I'm still here. And I got one more  game this year. I don't know how  well I'll play or even how much, but  I want you there.
How would you feel introducing your  drunk dad to all your friends? You  think about that?
I could live with it, if you could. (handing him a ticket) Here's a ticket. Section 2, Row 6.  Fifty yard line. If you don't come,  I'll never ask you again.
O.K., Joey. And good luck.
They give each other a short, quick hug. Nothing sentimen Joe walks back through the house. His dad stares out at t yard.
Darnell is up late again, studying at one of the tables. hears footsteps, becomes aware of the presence of another person. He looks up to see Autumn.
Hey, Autumn. How's Ray?
Don't know. Haven't seen him since  the night I saw you. He'd been goin'  out.
Monica Lambert.
You knew? Why didn't you tell me?
